pros: State benefits are amazing. I pay practically nothing for an amazing health insurance that covers the whole family. They allow you to work partial remote and have a hybrid flex work schedule whereby you can work 10 hour days, 4 days a week and take a day off every week.
cons: When I first started working at FIU they told me the job would never be remote, then they wanted to expand the department and because it would be over a million dollar cost, they decided to make it partially remote. Having a carousel of employees in and out of the office meant the physical expansion and purchase of desks and chair and monitors wouldn’t be necessary. They still have us working partial remote even though several people have requested full remote work. We worked fully remote during the pandemic and did a great job, but they still won’t let us work fully remote. The pay is very low (I get paid $55k) and under industry standard for sure. We haven’t received a cost of living increase in about 2 1/2 years now. The dental benefits aren’t very good but I’m not sure if that’s just FIU or something typical. The metrics for promotion are not clear and raises are very difficult to attain. Turnover rate is pretty bad.

job_title: Instructional Design Associate in Miami, FL
pros: One of the great advantages of working at FIU is the opportunity to gain valuable work experience after completing your undergraduate degree. As a recent graduate, starting your career at FIU can provide a wealth of opportunities to learn and grow in a supportive and dynamic environment. Another benefit of working at FIU is the flexibility offered by their hybrid work arrangement. This allows employees to work both from home and in the office, giving them the ability to work in a way that suits their personal preferences and lifestyle. This can be especially advantageous for those who have family or other commitments that require flexibility in their work schedule. Moreover, the management at FIU is known for being understanding and accommodating in the event of unforeseen circumstances or emergencies. This means that you can be assured that your employer will support you when you need it most, which can be incredibly reassuring and help you to maintain a healthy work-life balance. Finally, working at FIU means that you won't have to worry about being micromanaged, which can be a huge relief for those who prefer to work independently. This allows you to take ownership of your work and be creative and innovative in your approach, which can be incredibly fulfilling and lead to career advancement opportunities. In summary, working at FIU offers numerous benefits for recent graduates, including valuable work experience, a flexible work arrangement, supportive management, and the freedom to work independently. All of these factors make it an excellent choice for those looking to start their careers.
cons: While there are many positive aspects to working at FIU, there are also some potential downsides to consider. One of the most significant cons of working at FIU as an instructional designer is the limited ability to work from home fully. Despite the job primarily requiring computer work and minimal phone or in-person interaction, FIU does not allow employees to work remotely indefinitely. This lack of flexibility may be frustrating for some, especially those who may have other obligations that make commuting to work difficult. Additionally, FIU's policies regarding compensation and promotions may be a source of concern for some employees. Specifically, the lack of raises and the potential for outside hires to be offered higher positions than existing employees may feel unfair and demotivating. This can be especially frustrating for employees who have invested significant time and effort into the job and gained valuable experience. Overall, while FIU may be a good starting point for recent graduates, the limited ability to work from home fully and the lack of opportunities for career advancement may make it less appealing as a long-term career option. Employees may need to consider whether they are willing to accept these limitations or if they should look for other opportunities that offer more flexibility and potential for growth.

pros: The university provides great benefits. (health, dental, vision, etc)
cons:
University does not provide much support to the museums. In fact, there is a strange sense of animosity between uni employees and the art museum's staff. There also seems to be issues with providing their employees with the proper pay. Many staff members within the museum are not being paid the appropriate salary based on their skills and job duties. Not sure if this is an issue coming from the university or executive staff decisions. 

There is also a major diversity issue. Many of the staff are cis gender white or white passing women, and if there are any poc they often don't stay very long or have no other choice but to stay due to personal life circumstances. The director performs diversity and equity only when it suits the image of the museum. If a donor comes along with enough money, they quickly change course and bend to get money. There is not enough effort put into educating staff on issues of race, gender, and sexual orientation. They are accepting of people, but harbor many biases and lack interest in growing and learning. 

They're a university museum that does not center their work around the student body. Instead they choose to exploit their students for labor and branding purposes. They want more interns and students to give them all the latest information, tips, and tricks with whats trending to bring in more students, but do not have many paid opportunities for students.

pros: Tuition and health insurance are covered with graduate assistantships.

pros: Students were fantastic - bright, energetic and collaborative. Eager to work on scientific research. It was the best part of the job! Administrative support staff were fantastic and friendly - ensured a laboratory’s needs were met. They were very professional. Beautiful campus and nice community.
cons: Cons outweigh the pros. Very little support for safe working environments for women and female scientists/researchers/faculty/staff. If a problem with a supervisor or mentor was reported, it was ignored or minimized. HR and Title IX officers were given no power to help trainees. AWED office was supportive, but power to assist women researchers was limited by higher administration. Multiple reports of harassment and bullying go nowhere. Either you get put on administrative leave or have to leave the university in the middle of your research project, due to a lack of protection by FIU. Ethical research was also not supported. Reports of research integrity concerns were delayed until you leave or are fired. If an inquiry does happen, it was a biased process that supports the person accused. Thus, the university allows federal research funds to be misused and research to be performed in unsafe environments for women. Female scientists and trainees also do not have an equal opportunity for promotion, and often aren’t invited for interviews in some departments. Many male-dominated science departments still exist at FIU, and there is little opportunity for women to move into higher positions. Diversity exists because of the location of the university in Miami, but equity and inclusion were not obvious. Hispanic/Latin voices were not always welcomed to the table in biomedical research. Many of the Hispanic/Latin folks were kept in lower level administrative positions and not at those of the professor, Chair or Dean levels. It was discouraging.

cons: Low pay in general (Part-time positions). Low pay for the volume of work (many of the full time positions). Sometimes hard to find help on projects or answers to complicated questions because the university is still relatively young. You may have to search high and low for people who have the answers you need depending on the subject.

And in my department, the politics were toxic, manipulative drama out of a reality TV show. Furthermore, I was disturbed by their tokenizing, savior approach to the predominately nonwhite student population. The university uses the ethnic diversity of the students as a recruiting tool but does not always support that diversity. Hate speech, white supremacy, and harassment were tolerated, even by the President, who decided that jokes about assaulting Latinas on campus were OK. The university is also scammy, from the guy who sells cruises to students in the student union building (Graham Center) to the employee benefits providers who repeatedly come to your office to try to sell you life insurance.

job_title: Division of IT in Miami, FL
pros: Sense of community and  great benefits.
cons:
Salary was very low and in my case benefits didn’t compensate the low salary considering how many hours I was working from home. 
The department I worked for was not good. I worked for the Division of IT and my managers had little to no sense of employee’s personal time and life balance. I was working more than 10 hours daily and taking calls from home outside of my work hours to solve issues for users and servers. There was not on-call schedule and direct manager was abusive, condescending, and irresponsible. There was little to no appreciation for arduous work and dedication. Most of the time I felt burned out, tired, and without the ability to accommodate for planning and research, this resulted in poor work performance.
 Technologies and updates were rushed constantly without proper planning just to gain an advantage on other departments.  Constant warfare with other members of the Division and managers based on salary and performance.

pros:
This is about FIU ONLINE.
Instructional Designers get compensated well.
Instructional Designers get extensive training.
Room for advancement. 
Project oriented.
Opportunity to attend conferences and other professional development.
cons:
Unhealthy competition. 
Extremely territorial. 
If you're disliked by the wrong person, depending on whose home they've visited after hours, your life becomes a living hell on the job. 
They love rumors, gossip and anything that makes their perceived competition look bad, I guess you can say this could be any job, but the pretense they put on makes this situation special. 
You have a Executive who doesnt know Instructional Design and after a while.on the job, finally starts to teach a class, but passed it on to an Instructional Designer to teach for him, because he had no time. 
Oh, and while facing this internal crud, you still have onery faculty to contend with and if they complain, you're fired; might take a while, but its happening. Even if they have to get folks to make it up, or hire someone that looks like you so you cant claim discrimination. 
Yes, very unique place, indeed.

job_title: Senior Special Events Manager in North Miami, FL
pros: Awesome University.  FIU really cares about its students and how they learn and eventually matriculate through the University into the real world.   FIU employs real world industry professionals to teach real world experiences alongside of its core of teaching professionals to provide a theory and application based education model.
cons:
Unfortunately satellite campuses fall into the culture of exemption in which resources are dedicated to the expansion of the main campus which draws away from the University's real advantage... a campus located mere feet away from the ocean.   If FIU would recognize its advantages that set them apart from sillier Universities, then they may just be able to accomplish the impossible.

In my honest opinion, the University has the potential to evolve into something really special.  The politics involved in keeping individuals (employees) from reaching their potential has created a culture of stagnancy where the strongest individuals leave through coercion (where by their own accord or not).  Unfortunate as it it, its a culture that  permeates throughout its core.

review_title: An Un-bias Review from a Truthful, non-bitter employee
pros: There are opportunities for growth as its still very much a growing university.  However, it will highly depend on your deparement and which members of management you have over you.
cons: Its difficult to know where to start.  Upper management is under qualified, unprofessional, and not willing to work together for the general "good" of the university, students, or athletic programs.  I was amazed by many circumstances where I or others were in need of help and were simply told "thats not my job."  If FIU is ever going to get better they need to promote the good employees, get rid of the bad/lazy employees, reward those that work hard and recognize ability.  They have a HUGE turnover problem, and attitude problem and no one is competent enough to fix it.  Its sad.

review_title: Some good, but many internal problems
pros: Plenty of departments to move around if you don't like where you are, flexible schedule, salary increases
cons: Despite words from the higher-ups, advising is not student-focused. High case loads make it difficult to make an impact, and with other tasks required (not specifically listed in job description, but rather are part of the "other tasks as necessary" category) face-to-face interaction is forced to be quick and un-impactful. Bare minimum work is acceptable. Lack of communication between departments, faculty, and leadership has brought upon many problems. Leadership makes you feel dumb if you don't understand something, and because of this people are afraid to ask questions. I also believe this attitude is transferred from leadership to employees and transferred to students (who are then afraid of seek help).

review_title: An overall positive experience and valuable learning opportunity.
pros: I truly enjoyed working at Florida International University (FIU) South Campus.  Prior to working at FIU, I was employed by a small college with very limited resources.  While at FIU, I worked in a well-equipped and stocked laboratory and wanted for nothing in terms of supplies.  I was able to attend classes around my work schedule, and received invaluable training opportunities that still serve me well, 10 years after my employment there.  I would encourage qualified job seekers in the South Florida area to apply to FIU, as there is opportunity for growth and development.
cons: I have no complaints about FIU per se, as my experience was quite positive.  For job seekers outside of the South Florida market, please note:  the cost of living in Miami is quite high.  Several of my colleagues lived outside of Miami-Dade county and commuted to work daily.  The drive was simply too far for me, so I searched and found an affordable apartment in a nearby, older neighborhood.

pros: Good benefits as far as health, vacation, and sick.
cons: The administration is horrible. You can spend weeks waiting for someone to turn a call or email. Students are definitely not a priority, the faculty are. Higher administration only cares about the amount of money faculty bring in, not the students. I had HUNDREDS of students walk into my office complaining that nobody is able to help them. No matter the department or office, students are thrown to the bottom. Staff does whatever they want as far as hours or vacation, because nobody cares. They take time off during the busiest time of the year or they show up to work at 11 am. It seems as if nobody really cared.  If you ever want a raise....GOOD LUCK! That will never happen. After years of negotiation, the university finally increased our salaries by 1%!! It's absurd and insulting. Also, there is absolutely no space to grow.

review_title: Good job, but decisions made in a vacuum
pros: I have some great colleagues throughout the University. You can work with some autonomy and empowerment if your supervisor allows (mine does). President Rosenberg listens to students' input.
cons: Big decisions seem made in a vacuum with poor communication through the ranks. The smaller, north (Biscayne Bay) campus is often over-looked. Enrollment there went from 7,000 to 5,000 two years later; more classes should be offered. I hear that we don't want to be thought of as a commuter campus, but what can you expect when coffee shops, bookstores, and restaurants close at 2pm on Fridays and aren't open at all on Sundays? We don't pay very well, though academic departments seem to earn more than student affairs.

review_title: Be warned about the electrical engineering department
pros: Fellowship pays for college, and the university itself is cheaper than most places.
cons: The chair of this department is without a doubt the rudest person i have ever worked for! He insults students & workers, plays favorites, and 75% of his employes some of the biggest, whiniest charlatans i have ever met in my life with horrible work ethic. The entire department is a huge mess, and i don't feel like i got a good education here. The guy who trained me had NO idea what he was doing, and ordering stuff was a nightmare. It's almost impossible to get people to follow through on what they are saying. If you are persistant, you might get something done, but you wouldn't make any friends in the process. If you ask people to do there jobs, or follow through on there word, you'll get treated like a jerk because work is soooo horrible. Nobody wants to help you. If you want to do electrical engineering, my strong suggestion is to go elsewhere.

review_title: Great if you are student working there while finishing your degree, but leave as soon as you are done...
pros: A lot of flexibility if you are a student there. Flexible schedule and time off, though this depends heavily on the department you work for and who your direct supervisor is. Great opportunity to get some work experience (if you can get a job related to your field of study) and to meet other people.
cons: So relaxed at times that makes you so comfortable you may not want to leave. If you want a comfortable job where you can get by easily (as long as you get your work done) that's ok, but if you are looking for challenging work and to work on other things, then leave as soon as you can after finishing your degree.

review_title: FIU is behind in opportunities and gets little recognition and support to its graduates.
pros: You get to live in Miami, the campus is nice, the weather is warm, the education is really top notch but the university gets little recognition for it's quality  (and difficulty) of education.
cons: They want you to stay broke, the cost of living in this city makes it difficult to live on the salary you are given, the professors can be difficult to work with, not too different than being a grad student anywhere else.

pros: Working on campus is a great experience because it helps broaden your connections and gives one the chance to meet many people who come from different places with different goals. This helps to increase one's network and helps to make one well-rounded and more open-minded.
cons: There are not many cons, but although FIU is a great experience and a great place to work at, because it is such a large school that focuses on so many different areas, processing paper work can take more time than necessary and can often be a hassle because of it.

cons:

pros: I've been able to work in several areas of the University which has given me a great overview of how it all works. Colleagues are, for the most part, really nice people who work well together
cons: I've found it very tough to get raises over the years. It is a state-assisted University so that probably plays a part in that. State funding has been cut to all public universities in Florida year after year. University Leadership doesn't often provide input as to their expectations. It is common to have to develop plans, reports, projects, etc. and then have the boss react to it, as opposed to getting input at the beginning stage.

cons: The salary is a little bit low. The university is in latino community,  a lot of persons can`t speak English, such as restaurant, supermarket, autoshop etc.

job_title: Assistant Director, Faculty Development in Miami, FL
pros: Flexible work schedule, excellent benefits, beautiful campus. My current supervisor has made my time at FIU entirely worth-while. If it weren't for her, I would have left a while ago. She's incredibly knowledgeable, challenging, cutting edge, and determined to pursue a clear vision with clear goals. I'm lucky to work for her.
cons: It's hard to push innovation as people seem to be okay with status quo. Sometimes people seem scared of trying new things and failing, and they don't think of risks and challenges as opportunities for further learning. Anything that seems to rock the boat is strongly opposed.

review_title: It's and ok environment to work in.
pros: Excellent company benefits, ability to extend and complete your education and or if you have a child they can complete their education. Good work life balance, basically you will be able to have quality time with your family.  If you value helping students complete their higher education this is the place to be!  The greatest satisfaction is attending graduation and watching your students receive their degree. It will leave you speechless knowing you were a part of the process.
cons: lots of red tape, takes time to get things through the chain of command, moderate compensation, lots of politics

pros: They are really supportive of DACA and foreign students.  They help transfer students and have really good credit transfer programs.  There Veteran (which I am) program is fantastic, with early registration (a must, see cons...) and a helpful student veteran support group.
cons: The engineering department does not have enough staff to offer enough classes.  Although it did not happen to me, I know a few people who's graduation was pushed back because they were not able to get into the classes they needed to take in sequence.  There is also a problem with rampant cheating.  Some students who truly do not belong as engineers will graduate with decent GPAs.

review_title: A minority serving institution, with a new definition for the word Minority (International Student)
pros:
- Beautiful location, surrounding, weather, environment
- Lots of eye candy attraction/distraction to lure young minds
- Preferable for people willing to make their way to the top, starting from the very bottom
cons:
- Money is nowhere to be found in Miami
- The Teaching Assistants are underpaid, especially considering the expensive lifestyle of such metropolitan city like Miami
- International students are left stranded in an isolated life, not being taken care of properly by University community
- Sometimes assistantship positions requires doing low level work, which international students are forced to do, rather risk academic future in order to pay tuition and bills.

pros: Many opportunities. There are tons of different departments to work for on campus. This is both good and bad. Most departments have fantastic leadership, but some are lacking. The hours are generally 9 to 5.
cons: When you're dealing with students, it's almost always the case that they're going to ask you a question that cannot by answered by your department and they will have to speak with 2+ other departments to get a complete answer. This is frustrating to the student and thus they take out their frustration on you. Unfortunately, the university is so divided in it's functions that even things that should logically be handled together are separate departments in separate buildings.

review_title: low accountability is good and bad
pros: The benefits as a full time staff are great and include tuition waivers if you want to advance your education. FIU fosters further skill development and professional development which is always a plus.
cons: FIU has a culture that tends to push work off to the next person, very few employees take the extra effort to resolve an issue without just redirecting you down a long line of people. Often peers will avoid work rather than support one another as a community.

pros: All the resources, people, connections and events you would want/need for an optimistic entrepreneur/engineer
cons: Engineering professors don't show you how to use any of the software/hardware (hands-on) themselves, Instead push the job to a grad student to teach all hands-on material.  So prepare to teach yourself (or learn from another student) the most critical experiences necessary to land a job.

review_title: Great place to work, if you're a student or high up the food chain.
pros: FIU has great benefits and a laid back atmosphere.  Working there while being a student is great and management was very flexible with course/work schedules.
cons: Raises are hard to come by.   A great job and great review at the end of the year yields a whopping $0.10 raise.  Not much, but what more can you expect for a student position.

review_title: A complete disaster of an organization
pros: I spent over a year working there and I can honestly say that there are no pros to being employed by FIU Online.  There are absolutely no redeeming qualities that I could point to.  Every day is worse than the next.  Unless you're desperate for a paycheck, you'd be much happier working somewhere else.
cons: There are too many cons to mention in this small section, but it begins with a total lack of leadership, strategy or competence. The entire management structure of FIU Online is incapable of making a correct decision, on any issue, ever. To offer a comparison, if the management of FIU Online ran a funeral parlor, nobody would die.

review_title: Florida International University--- A stepping stone-- A must read
pros: The best part about working at FIU is that it is an upcoming university and your ideas can easily be utilized and implemented. Alot of positions possess a great amount of independence with little to no oversight.
cons:
The downside of FIU is that upper managements, directors, deans etc, do not know what their staff workers do on an everyday basis. Some management do not even know your work description and therefore recognition is not given and evaluations are a joke. There is a severe lack of structure at FIU and enforcement of a strategic plan.  

Be careful as to which College you apply for, take a look at the number of employees, student to professor ratio etc, and before working at FIU try to speak to someone from within that department or college you are seeking employment. Not all is bad, but very few departments are worth it. It is a young university with lots of changes underway, if you are looking for work at a "real university" apply at a school in north or central Florida. 

 FIU is like the mickey mouse of universities, the students treat it as an extension of high school and do not respect administration or staff. Some employees barely speak English and the customer service is severely lacking. 

There are constant changes in restructuring departments and units overall and the university has been undergoing budget cuts for the past few years. There is an overall sense of instability and the common phrase spoken at FIU is "we should be lucky we have a job." This goes to show that employees treat FIU as nothing more than a paycheck and they often do not speak up about problematic issues within their departments. 

There is also a sense that there is lot of inside trading of information, employees do not feel comfortable seeking employment elsewhere in the university because "everyone knows everyone."  Although a sense of community exists, it also works to your disadvantage. 

There is a clear glass ceiling at FIU, my professionals at FIU take years to move up so to speak and each position requires way too much education to earn poor pay. For example, most coordinator positions start off at 34000-40000, with a MASTER's degree.  Then the raises are very low and some years you will not earn a raise. Luckily the univeristy just implemented a new evaluation process for the entire university, in the past it was up to your department to evaluate you based on ....their own standards if there were any. There is still a sense that you earn a raise if you "friends" with the HR person for your department. 

There is also a terrible misuse of funds in some departments, some will use Foundation money to fund ridiculous items when instead those funds can be better used for scholarships, events etc. 

If you are coming from a private sector job, you may hate FIU completely. Most employees find this place to be a "good starter job" and do not anticipate long term employment.  The people that rave about FIU are those who think FIU is the only university in the United States, remember FIU is the only public univeristy in south florida and the only other main choice is UM a private school with a spectular student body. Pretty much if you apply you will get in. There is rolling admission so it is hectic for working in admission and some students are admitted the first week of classes, sometimes after classes have started.

FIU has potential, but it is far from being Worlds Ahead which is a new campaign to rebrand the image of the study body, faculty, staff and administrators. I think the new president of FIU is leading the university is a positive direction however there is a lot of cleaning house to do. 

There are too many Modesto minded employees and finally the focus is moving toward the students.

review_title: Adjuncts receive little respect or consideration from students and university personnel
job_title: Online Course Instructor in Miami, FL
pros: If you have the right department head, there are opportunities to create your own course as you see fit, particularly if you teach online courses.
cons:
* Apathetic students who disregard information about deadlines and assignment requirements and still expect an A in the course.
* Apathetic bureaucracy who seem unable to provide the most basic information or make it easily accessible.
* Course technicians who disregard direct instructions or who fail to fulfill their responsibilities or who care more about conformity than what works best for the course.  Plus, they're only evaluated once a year instead of every semester, forcing you to wait for problems to get worse over time.

pros: Depending on where you work management can be great. If you are a full-time employee the benefits I have heard are fantastic.
cons: It is a bit disappointing that employees need to pay for parking. If management does not listen they can be a con as well.

pros: I liked the positive environment and energy that employees and customers would share. y Since I was a store manager, I had a flexible schedule and a good salary with the opportunity to try and improve the company in different aspects.
cons: The main con about working in this company was that it was open on most holidays. Also, the fact that there wasn’t a lot of room for growth once you had reach certain point.

review_title: Working at FIU and Miami, FL
job_title: Applications Developer I in Miami, FL
pros: FIU is one of the largest public universities in Florida.  It is located in one of the most unique locations in the country, Miami.  As a large university (50K+ students enrolled), there are jobs available for almost any vocation.  They are always in need of staff and administrative personnel.  Faculty positions are also available for those with the right credentials and research/publishing experience.  Many employees stay due to the excellent benefits, such as affordable group health insurance, generous vacation/sick time, paid federal holidays.
cons:
Since FIU is a very large school, your experience on the job will vary a lot depending on the department and team you work with.  Middle and upper administrative positions can become competitive and cutthroat.  A department or team may not be the most positive and functional, and office politics may make work harder.  The flip side is also true, if you land a job with a great team, your work life with be great.  
Advancement for lower to middle administrative and staff positions is very slow.  People tend to stay until retirement at FIU so moving up takes forever.  
Miami is also a very expensive city to afford.  Prices to buy or rent a house are some of the highest of any major city in the country.  Also, the culture shock is quite real if you don't speak Spanish.  Most of Miami speaks Spanish as a first language, which might make it harder to be understood.

job_title: Student Assistant in North Miami, FL
pros: flexible schedule, you can do homework when it isn't busy, not too much work, you get to plan events, Easy interview, lots of other student assistants, you can work here up to a year after graduation, you can get hired and ask them to grant you work study as financial aid and they will.
cons: poor management, lack of communication between managers and student employees, poor event planning, relatively low wage. $10/hr, 20 hours a week, You can work closer to 30 hours if you're a work study employee.

review_title: FIU has had a great impact on my career development, allowing me to become the professional that I am today.
pros: Friendly and laid back environment, great place to work where one can grow as a professional. FIU provides opportunities for all those who are willing to work hard and are self motivated to see their goal accomplished.
cons: Being a public institution sometimes things take a little longer than expected, the desicion making process may involve many layers delaying the final outcome.

review_title: It's a tranquil place to work with no much opportunity to advance
pros:
- co-workers are very nice and friendly and they are willing to explain things.
- They are flexible with your work schedule, especially if you are taking classes in the university or if you are sick or have a personal emergency.
cons:
- Low wages and there is not much opportunities to advance.
- Sometimes there is low collaboration among departments and getting things done

pros: Large international study body brings an interesting mix of experience and perspective to the classroom.
cons: Little freedom to plan or structure my classes.  I was required to teach "the program," which required a great expenditure of time for very little pay. Also, there was little support from management when problems with students arose.

pros: Good diversity. If you get bored there is lot to enjoy. Spanish is must here. Recently they have hired many professors from good universities. I hoping they will do their best to improve the departments
cons: The infrastructure should improve. The departments needs more funds for the development. Also the engineering centre is boring and there are no proper restaurants here. The girls are distracting since they are very hot. lol

pros: Great campus, vibrant and growing community. Students from all around the world. Staff is usually helpful too. College of business is getting into better rank positions every year
cons: You have to have a car to get there, public transportation is not good; the cost of living in the city is expensive and there are not many options for housing around too

job_title: Instructional Designer in Saint Augustine, FL
pros: FIU is an excellent workplace due to the family feel. Everyday you can learn something different at FIU. It is my first medium (large) institution.
cons: It is really a large institution and sometimes the right hand does not know what the left hand is doing, such as FIU Online and Blended courses. They are separate and often clueless of the other.

pros: excellent education in many fields
cons:
expensive to international students and not giving incentives to students with high GPA
Not all the professors in the biostatistics department are carefully selected and the way they teach is not as desired. For example, Dr Khan teaching is like we are in a math class and the students are getting A but they don't understand anything, and he is not equally treating people, and you are not allowed to ask any question in the class. the student evaluate him great because he is going to give them A.

pros: Great benefits and work life balance can be achieved.  Within reason there is opportunities for development and promotion.  You also have the satisfaction of seeing your work affect the community.
cons: The politics can be exhausting and sometimes get in the way of doing a job well. Additionally, salaries tend to be on the lower side of the scale, until you are a higher up and then you can make a competitive salary.

review_title: Great working environment with great people to work with.
job_title: Biological Science Lab Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: You are given the freedom and encouraged to express your ideas and creative side. Very supportive faculty. Fun working environment. Great people, always ready to help and always happy.
cons: Not always a glamorous job. Going out to remote sites in the everglades, but that's where the research was conducted. Pay could use and increase, but everyone thinks that about every job. There isn't many cons to working at FIU.

review_title: Good environment and opportunities. Not really well payed.
pros: The institution has a good Developing Career plan. It also provides benefits such as health care, daycare, the Multicultural environment is fenomenal. You can learn a lot from it. They also give you Trainings and workshops. Its Great educational developing opportunities.
cons: They work is a very Very hierarchical system. Its hard to find spaces to promote changes and collaborative development. Decisions come from above and people are afraid to question. Its a way to keep it controlled since its such a big complex

job_title: Enrollment and Recruitment Manager in Miami, FL
pros:
Benefits
Lots to take part in
Engages in work life balance
Interdisciplinary opportunities
cons: Depending on the department you may have a great culture or an unhealthy one. There's not one culture that surrounds the entire university. Not much oversight/check in to how departments are run.

pros: It is a dynamic environment. It is great to contribute to fulfilling the mission of the University. Sincere commitment to the community.
cons: Because of the long-standing history of underfunding for education and more recent budget shortfalls for education in Florida, it is challenging to deliver all the programs and services needed for students, faculty and staff.

pros: Nice atmosphere on campus. Parking is easy to find. People friendly, good choices of restaurants on campus. You get the state benefits package which is very good. Employer matches IRA contributions and you are already vested. Facilities are relatively new and actually have windows so you don't feel like you're working in a dungeon.
cons: Poor place to do a post-doc. Lack of organizations representing post-doc's interests. Total lack of interest in helping post docs find positions when they finish.

review_title: My experience working in Florida International University has been a mix of both positive and negative experiences.
pros: Great Student Job as it is located on Campus, the hourly pay is not bad for a student job, plenty of on-campus venues to eat, hours are flexible and supervisors generally work around your class schedule
cons: The workload is rather tedious, sometimes feel as though the office environment is mismanaged, training period is rather arduous and lengthy, rigidly established hierarchy of positions where movement between positions may be lengthy and somewhat inefficient

review_title: Research Assistant at the Adaptive Neural Systems Laboratory
pros:
- Flexible work schedule
- Good pay for someone who is still in school
- Convenient if you go to school there as well
- Good location around plenty of restaurants and stores
- Academic culture
- Very independent work environment
- Lots of opportunities to learn if you take advantage
cons:
- Not for you if you aren't a self-starter
- Too many different people acting as a supervisor and giving conflicting directions

review_title: FIU is overall a great place to work
pros:
The environment is great at FIU because it's so dynamic,
Most department leaders make working at FIU enjoyable
There are a lot of events around campus
Lots of food choices in FIU and nearby
You can usually see how your work impacts the FIU community
cons:
There are hardly any annual raises -- 1% if you're lucky
Most departments have no growth opportunities
There is a lot of re-shuffling of departments/divisions and that can be scary
The overall pay is only decent for comparable jobs outside of FIU

review_title: A relaxed culture and nice environment make this a good place to work
pros: Great locations, relaxed culture. Good side benefits in the community since the university puts on events all around Miami. Accessible by bus fairly easily from Downtown.
cons: No critique of FIU is complete without complaining about parking. The pricing scheme for employees is downright unfair. In software terms, there's a problem with keeping the status quo, even if it's mediocre.

review_title: Overall, I have a good experience working at FIU. But it also depends on the department you work in.
pros: Its has good employee benefits, such as tuition waiver, low cost health insurance, opportunity to advance within the university. It is a good environment to work in.
cons: Of course, salary is lower than in private organization in general. Salary increase is no less deceiving. You have to really fight for an increase, based on personal experience.

review_title: FIU is a great place to work! Really, it is!
pros:
great benefits and vacation leave
relaxed atmosphere
professional development and growth
tuition waiver
insurance
cons:
employees pay for annual parking, its not expensive but still
depending on your role, it may be hard to truly take a vacation if you dont have back up or have a fear of your work piling up. but it is still encouraged to have your work life balance
driving far to work ( i live north of MMC so working at BBC would save me gas and time).

review_title: Nice multi-cultural environment to learn and work.
pros: You get to find people from several countries, which gives you the opportunity to get some insights about their cultural influences and also learn to be more open minded.
cons: Language barrier might be a difficulty in interacting with new comers. Sometimes even with senior people. But it can be worked out.

review_title: Overall positive, but increasingly profit-driven attitudes endanger a commitment to quality education.
pros: Hands-on approach that let's you become engaged if you want to be engaged. Good opportunities to get exposure if you are willing to put in the time and effort.
cons: Focus on short term profit at the expense of commitment to long term vision of academic excellence. Little respect for work life balance.

pros: Some good people (faculty, staff and students). beautiful campus, great vacation and sick leave, 7 credits of coursework paid for passing classes,
cons: low salaries, a few lazy apples in the bunch, technology services unable to keep up with growth and needs of students, staff, and faculty.  Some lazy workers fluff their feathers like they do a lot, but barely can be found if something needs to be done. very annoying.

pros: It is awesome working at StartUP FIU because you learn a lot about entrepreneurship and the my manager gives me a lot of freedom. She allows me to pursue what I am interested and I have learned so much from being a part of it .It is very ambiguous and vague so you have to be okay with working without a system
cons: It is ambiguous so if you are self-motivated or innovative it is not the place for you.

review_title: Working 20 Hours a Week is Amazing!
pros:
You get to expand on your skills on the class you are working on
You get to improve your social skills by talking to people
You get to improve on how to walk people through problems
10 hours per month is a little less than $400, and 20 hours per month is about a little less than $800.
cons: You have to be aware of students who don't want to do their work or are rude to you.

pros: Job security in my opinion is very good in this organization. If a department is having job cuts they will try to place you in another department.
cons: Salary is not up to par with other organization but job security and benefits make up for it. Tuition reimbursement if a plus.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: It's a comfortable working place, where you may balance your career while maintaining a personal and social life. There's always people willing to help and give sincere advice , and most importantly colleagues don't send any negative competitive vibes towards you.
cons: it's definitely not a dream job nor a job that gives you a huge sense of achievement, but it's always nice to start with a humble job until you master your skills and work your way uphill.

pros:
You are given flexible scheduling based on your classes and to some extent other personal engagements
Sometimes you will have enough time on your hands to study your coursework
You get to work with your peers and build your teamwork skills
cons: You probably won't receive any raises so whatever your base pay may be, it will remain the same throughout your entire employment.

review_title: Great opportunity to meet important people at the university depending on which department you work at.
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Miami, FL
pros:
Networking
Decent pay
Free services and discounts
Good staff to work with who are willing to teach you a lot and mentor
Free email account 
Student Microsoft Office
Faculty Parking
cons:
Not many hours to go around for students depending on your department.
Very competitive work environment depending on department
Some jobs can be boring.

job_title: Coordinator, Administrative Services in Miami, FL
pros: Great place to start working as a full-time employee.
cons: After taking on a supervisory role, growing further in the university can be a challenge for young professionals.

pros: Supportive environment. Management is making the right choices to assure continued growth over the foreseeable future. Great benefits package including retirement fund, medical, dental, vision, etc.
cons: Space is at a premium. The university has grown so rapidly that the infrastructure is lagging behind. Additionally, parking is always difficult.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: Great facilities, very nice campus with good amenities such as gyms, walkways, etc.
cons: Faculty in the science departments are not inspirational. Most of them just worry about receiving tenure and then stop doing research.

review_title: I was very excited to become a part of the university Advancement Division
job_title: Director of Membership and Development in Miami Beach, FL
pros: Excellent Team, state of the art database, supportive atmosphere
cons: Merger/Take-over of Jewish Museum of Florida ( my then employer) took a hostile turn as leaders could not agree and move forward efficiently with necessary tasks, hindering productivity.

review_title: I am graduate research assistant in Florida International University which it is a vibrant and fast improving university
pros: It has a multicultural environment and I have a chance to meet students from all over the world. Besides, working with students and professors, I learn how to be a good engineer and also a researcher
cons: Engineering Center in FIU is not located in main campus. So, most of student have been deprived of using facilities in main campus.

pros: Flexible hours and small teams. Professor puts priority in our classes than our work. Very chill and relax environment.
cons: No room for growing. If you're a student you get paid a flat fee according to the university system. I didn't get a raise until I went to grad school cause the university says under grads have to be X amount. Don't expect medical and any good benefits if you're not full time

pros: You gain a lot of experience working at FIU. Leadership and teamwork is very important. And there can be a lot of opportunity for growth.
cons: It is kind of hard to get your foot in the door at FIU, but once you do, growth is easy.

pros: I have flexibility to work. Weekly I had to sign on for 10 hours and I choose work time on my preference.
cons: Some works had time limit to finish, so I had to finish those works within the time limit.

pros:
Every semester they take you on an employee trip somewhere to team bond.
one hour paid breaks on 8 hour shifts. 
Nice work area in an office with AC and high tech.
Employees/colleges are nice
cons:
Pay isn't the best.
Growing in the company mainly happens if the bosses boss likes you and are bias towards you .

review_title: Good place for entry level experience
pros: Depending what department you are in, FIU can be a very flexible and laid back environment. sometimes employees can feel like they are not being challenged enough and become bored with their position
cons: The salary is poor especially for the cost of living. sometimes moving up the ranks takes long and you can encounter some bias

review_title: Florida International University...great environment, great employer
pros: This is a really great environment to work. It's friendly, and a rather great place to be. Management is competent, reliable and friendly as well. Lots of room for growth. The university is definitely going places, and so are it's employees! Upper management communicates rather well with everyone else, and the chain of command is rather clear and concise.
cons: Not as innovative as it could possibly be.

pros: FIU is an amazing place to work due to the population diversity and benefits, specially the benefits. I really enjoyed working at FIU!
cons: The only thing that made me look for another job was the salary. Salaries are low at FIU and it is very hard to either get a raise or get promoted. People dont just get promoted, they still have to apply and go through the whole process.

pros: A top university with amazing students, faculty and staff.
cons: Central not focused on the ball: getting the university ranked and pushing all the colleges towards excellence.  Some colleges are top 10 in the world and others no one has ever heard off.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: The university has a lot of resources. The college cares about it's students. The campus is diverse and always growing and innovating.
cons: For living in Miami, the pay really isn't that good. I know we're graduate students but the cost of living in Miami is ridiculous. Plus this school is a commuter school so the costs in driving are also high. Parking is horrible

pros: A nice work environment that allows you to work directly with nontraditional students fulfill their goal of coming back to school to finish their degree.
cons: There is very little room to grow in the department and receive promotions. Many people hold the same positions for entirely too long.

pros: Socially engaged institution with a mission of serving students overlooked by other schools. Great for social and economic mobility for its mostly working class student body. Majority minority school with great social impact.
cons: Still doesn't take environmental leadership seriously. Commuter school identity impacts campus life. Should take an even stronger leadership position regarding issues like housing affordability, social equity, transit accessibility, and criminal justice reform.

pros: Working with students is extremely enjoyable.  Many are very appreciative and thankful.  Hours and schedule are flexible, and it's probably the best job a student can have.
cons: Typical "office politics", dealing with coworkers and supervisors.  Thirty minute tutoring sessions are too short.  Working with college students that don't know fractions.

job_title: Lead Drupal Applications Developer in Miami, FL
pros:
You can do just enough and you won't get fired.
Great campus, don't really need to leave for anything, everything you will need during the day is there.
cons:
Never get raises.
Stuck in the same position forever no matter how hard you work
No remote work
Not IT friendly

review_title: I enjoy the job on campus
pros: It is convenient to work part-time on campus as a student. The working environment is superb.
cons: The experience get is limited. As the teacher's A the knowledge I use in daily work is what I have learnt from my class.

job_title: Library Student Assistant in Miami, FL
pros:
I worked as a student assistant and the base pay is higher  than minimum wage (9/hr)

Flexible  and lenient schedules (especially for students enrolled at the university)
cons:
Not much advancement opportunities past a certain level
Usually hires outside of the school for higher up positions

pros: FIU Spanish Department provides ample pedagogical support for incoming TA’s. Health insurance was a plus.
cons: The pay was very low.

job_title: Grad Student-Research Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: Florida Intl Univ is a friendly school, professors are always willing to help you. I got to learn a lot as a grad student here.
cons: Sometimes the lab work requires a lot of hours, weekends, holidays, but overall I learn a lot of techniques here.

pros: In my particular Office there is work/life balance which is really important to me in this stage of my life.  Good atmosphere.  The students keep you feeling young!
cons: Salaries aren't great for most.  They are more likely to hire someone from the outside than promote from within.

pros:
Help students 1 on 1. 
Good base pay 
Refresher material in case you forgot.
cons:
Students never show up to learning sessions. 
Bad communication between teacher and assistants so you go into class without knowing what to prep for.

job_title: Front Desk Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: Pay was good, benefits were good, flexible schedule for students
cons: Couldn't work more than 20 hours as a student ID, when there is no schoo, there is no work

pros: It is one of the good universities in the region. The working environment is really good. You can learn some practical work while studying at the same time.
cons: I do not really see any cons in working there but after all its a university not a company. Therefore there are some things that you can experience in the company and not in the university.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: - Get to work on amazing projects with brilliant professors
cons: - Not friendly to felons. I was fired after they conducted a background check although I had already been working for them for almost a year without incident. If I was as dangerous as they acted like I was, how was I able to get along with everyone for almost a year?

review_title: quite a good university, easy to get your master degree and have a lot of time to do your stuff.
pros: easy work, cover insurance and tuition fee. the professor will not push you so much.
cons: Not a good chance to practice your skills and the organization is a little loose.

job_title: Research Associate Professor in Miami, FL
pros:
Flexible. I love what I do.  I have no more comments 
 I think asking for a long comment does my makes sense.  It's best to be concise.
cons: Flexible.  Need to be self directed.   Ability to work on ones own. I have no other comments. I think asking for a long comment does my makes sense.  It's best to be concise

pros: You can work with people from all around the world, if you are a student you can work and study in the same place, you can reach hundreds of thousands of users with your projects, and you get to work with very creative and passionate professors.
cons: Bureaucracy. Not all teams are progressive.

job_title: Post Doctoral Research Associate in Miami, FL
pros: Although it is not a good fame university, it is a vibrant place. Lots of constructions are going on, and departments especial for bio-related are expanding. Good infrastructure, reasonable student, and nice weather.
cons: Because it is relative new, national recognition may not be great so far. Administrative process for a new employee is kind of slow at least for postdoc.

pros: Amazing upper management, family atmosphere and best of all Worlds Ahead Colleagues! This is the best employer in the State of Florida. This is the reason why they have been ranked constantly in the top 100 employers (currently 64) by Forbes Magazine.
cons: NONE!!! and I mean it. FIU is just that good.

pros: You get good time off and they pay part of your tuition. Most holidays are off, except a couple here and there.
cons: There is no leadership, as managers do not do their job. All departments struggle due to the incompetence of their employees as well as the lack of management. Compensation is veryyyyy low!

pros: It is a very good and diverse university. The weather in Miami is really good and you can enjoy a very good work and life balance if you want. Living cost there is OK, especially the housing is very low.
cons: Not good policy for international students. They change the policy a lot and usually have lots of constraints on students' internship choices.

pros: Paid time off, Health insurance, Retirement plans, on campus services/amenities, Good work/life balance, help with tuition for most programs, clean campus
cons: Rare growth opportunities, low pay, difficult to use all the Paid time off, parking fees are high for staff and difficult to find parking

review_title: An organization challenged by fear of change
pros: Is always becoming better, and growing. To a certain extent growth has been thought out, and investment has gone into areas where students can be employed.
cons: Is rather a disorganized organization, as every department / college tries to do things as it sees fit.

pros: Great institution to work for: Great benefits; beautiful Campus, employees feel that they are making an impact to the community.
cons: Too big too fast: The university has grown too rapidly which has created red tapes, silos  and inefficiencies. If you are applying, be patient because the hiring process may take a few months.

review_title: do not work for the college of business
pros: Great benefits and A LOT of PTO, academic environment, opportunity to help others
cons: the supervisor's "pets" can do as they please. no recognition for the those who truly work hard. College of business administration is corrupt and a mess and neither the president nor HR cares.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant, Good work while pursuing your degree
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: Flexible Hours, Health Insurance, On-campus employment convenient for international students.
cons: Not a great salary, not many career opportunities inside FIU.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Friendly environment. Everyone is very helpful and conducive to a positive work atmosphere.
cons: Growth is limited by the policies of the school. There is alot of misscommunication about salaries and the salary range is very low.

job_title: GC Student Employee in Miami, FL
pros: If your a student looking for a job, the Graham Center is the way to go. Reasonable pay and SUPER flexible with your hours.
cons: Sucks how with some easy jobs we aren't allowed to have our laptops out to do school work or something of the sort, especially with jobs where we are just sitting there.

review_title: Always improving but could be better
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Miami, FL
pros: R1 institution, so there's a huge focus on research and very novel, top of the line equipment for data collection. Many exciting projects and brilliant, motivated, young faculty and PIs.
cons: Not much internal funding. The cognitive neuroscience department is quickly expanding but has growing pains along the way in terms of organization and being clear on expectations.

pros: FIU provides great benefits to it's employees. The atmosphere is positive, promotes school spirit and comradery amongst staff and students alike and opportunities are available for furthering ones education, even as a full-time employee.
cons: Parking during the fall & spring semesters.

review_title: Graduate Assistant for Math and Stat Dept
pros: It was great working for the Math and Stat department at FIU. The hours are very flexible and the student are eager to learn.
cons: Perhaps the department could be a little bigger but maybe that isn't the concentration of the university at this point.

pros: Winter weather of Miami is good. One of the most diverse universities.
cons: FIU sucks. The quality of undergraduate education is terrible. FIU is enrolling more and more undergraduates sacrificing the quality. Quality of graduate education is poor as well. Faculties do little research and barely apply for external funding after the tenure approval. Poster competition inside the university is politicized.

review_title: Great opportunity to gain experience while getting your degree.
pros: Balance of time for courses and research. Co-workers and advisors for the most part all work well together. Excellent location in Miami.
cons: Parking is terrible no matter what time of the day or semester. Employee self service portal is very difficult to use. Really not many cons.

review_title: low pay, little support, sort of friendly
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in North Miami, FL
pros: The people at FIU are sort of friendly. The president of the university seems very friendly and intelligent, and he tries very hard to portray the school positively in the community.
cons: I found the majority to be overworked and underpaid. There isn't much room for growth unless someone dies or moves on.

review_title: Beautiful campus, nice people there. The staffs are helpful.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL
pros:
The weather, the landscape, the people are all very good. Living expenses are not very high, and lots of activities around the campus. 

The staffs on campus provides excellent services to faculties and students. You can just focus on your own things, they will handle the others.
cons: Too hot sometime in summer.

pros: A hard-working and diverse employee force.  Nice, friendly people and the management personnel were attentive and engaging.  The workload was not too heavy and I was trusted to do my job without being micromanaged.  Overall a great place to work.
cons: There are none that I can think of.

review_title: It's a great place to work.
job_title: Computer Support Specialist in North Miami Beach, FL
pros: The work environment is laid back. Everyone is very friends and nice. They require you to participate in professional development. Work at your own pace, and the workshops are great!
cons: Some people are too laid back. Makes it hard to get work done sometimes.

pros: Emerging Tier-one School in Engineering and Computer Science. The labs and research are very active and up to current needs of students.
cons: By far it has equal interest and it needs to stay ahead in some critical areas for it be more beneficial compared to other tier one schools.

pros: Benefits, vacation, flexibility. We have everything at FIU from a beauty salon where you can get a quick manicure/pedicure or a blow out on your lunch break to a Dry Cleaners. It is very convenient.
cons: Limited to no-growth in position, low pay with raises, no C.O.L.A. Unqualified people in high positions.

pros: The atmosphere is wonderful and welcoming! My supervisors and coworkers made me feel ike we were all family. If there is  something you do not understand thy are willing to explain or show you how to do it. Hours are flexible and great if you are a student.
cons: Nothing I can think of.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Miami, FL
pros: Great place to work and great co-workers. There is also opportunity to move up within FIU.
cons: I can't really think of anything bad when it comes to FIU maybe just parking at the beginning of each semester

pros: Nice location, beautiful campus and students are eager to learn.
cons: Parking, Inept management, high turnover of staff.

pros: FIU isn't going anywhere. The benefits are great.
cons: Depending on the job and starting position growth can be really slow but it is definitely possible as long as one stays professional at all times and is willing to put in the hard work and more. One has to be really intelligent in order to grow, cannot be passive.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in South Miami, FL
pros: Lots of options for advancement. You can go in any career direction you choose. Depending on the manager the scheduling is very flexible and they encourage growth.
cons: Parking is horrendous. You have to trek across campus especially during the first weeks of the semester.

review_title: Great way to pay your studies
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL
pros:
Flexible Hours
Health insurance is paid in part by the university 
Being a Graduate Research Assistant is a great way to finance your studies since it also pays most of your school costs
cons: Management is usually handled by faculty and as a result of this your responsibilities can vary widely depending on your advisor

pros: School of music is excellent. Faculty is string with several acclaimed teaching artists. String theory area as well.
cons: Location is not near any other major city. For this academic area that can cause isolation from other career opportunities.

job_title: Director Research Services in Miami, FL
pros:
Opportunity for education

that's pretty much it
cons: Elitist attitudes. You must be "one of the boys" to get anywhere. Also, FIU is highly bureaucratic, meaning that in order to get just one simple thing done, you have to go through many people.

review_title: Comfortable, great benefits, too many politics
pros: Most departments have a comfortable working environment. Great chance to get a degree with most of the tuition costs covered. Great benefits overall.
cons: Don't promote internal growth. Politics become overbearing. School is becoming greedy.

review_title: Excellent place for work and life
job_title: Tenure-Track Assistant Professor in Miami, FL
pros: This is my first full-time job after graduating from PhD. I really like this place, this city and this work. The colleagues are friends and helpful. The lifestyle is relaxed and multi-cultural. There is no snow like the cold Northeast and really lovely campus.
cons: Hot and humid in the summer.

pros: FIU is a great place to work. It is very family-oriented and everyone is always looking to help each other. Bosses are great, school schedule is respected, and benefits are some of the best you'll ever find. I recommend friends to work here.
cons: Pay is low; not enough to afford living in Miami.

review_title: Mixed feelings about FIU; Labs are Great; Admin, not always
job_title: Grad Student in North Miami, FL
pros: Great Facilities, good people, great scientists, mixed student body.
cons: Larger school admin-type offices are a bit slow in processing anything. Smaller departmental offices have great responsive people who often have to wait... Student body has a thorough mix of quality...from great to horrendous.

review_title: Working for FIU as a student assistant
pros: VERY flexible in accordance to your school schedule, easy accessibility and online training provided if needed.
cons: Poor pay,  disorganized internal structure and heavy politics ... like everywhere else. Point being is if your a student this is ideal for you.

review_title: Not bad, helps if you know some spanish
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: growing campus, well-funded, good benefits, nice gym, multicultural community
cons: traffic, parking, a lot of "not my job" people who make it difficult to get through bureaucracy, if you don't know any Spanish, it can be difficult to get things done.

pros: FIU has a wonderful environment and for the most part a great culture to work for. The people are down to earth and its overall a very enjoyable place to work.
cons: As a student assistant you are only allowed to work 20 hours a week, however this is no fault to the school.

review_title: Great place to work for college jobs!
pros: As a student living on campus, the location was extremely convenient (no car needed to drive/park).  They also sponsor international students.
cons: For student jobs, growth is limited and pay is minimal.

job_title: IT Generalist II in Miami, FL
pros: Great benefits, generous sick and vacation time, lots of services on campus.
cons: You have to pay for parking yourself, ($100-$200 per year) and during peak months it can be very hard to find a spot that does not require you to walk 20 minutes to your office.

pros: FIU has great staff all around, a student body that is great to work with, and a campus that is a pleasure to call home during the work day.
cons: Miami traffic is always a great thing, but FIU is located out by the turnpike so that is helpful.

review_title: Florida International University is a outstanding university with a diverse field of jobs.
pros: Great environment to work at and to gain experience. Very Flexible schedule.
cons: Compensation was the worse for me but that's because I worked In the library as a Librarian Assistant. $8/hour.

pros: Very supportive of you pursuing degree so flexible schedule. Also friendly work environment within walking distance from food areas
cons: The Upward mobility slow, as well as you have to fight for salary increases however they make you comfortable to stay in your position

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL

cons: Due to department shifts, some faculty members starter acting questionable. Sometimes the workload was overwhelming, but most of the time it was a good working environment.

pros:
Opportunity for growth
Decent Salaries
Great benefits
Excellent Work Environment
cons: Tendency to have a committee for everything. Generally, it is a higher education problem where no one wants to take responsibility for decision making.

review_title: Some of the best years of my life
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL

My advisor was awesome and continues to be a friend and valuable connection to this day. I got a lot of valuable experience including writing successful grant proposals and learning how to budget. 
Pay was pretty good
cons: I hate Miami (not FIU's fault, obvs)

pros: Great place to work, everyone is super nice. Learned a lot.

pros: Size, overall great people, breadth of organization, VPs are hard working, great administration, good work/life balance, strategic focus

pros: Growing entity; students are respectful and hardworking and you have an opportunity to further your education at no cost.

pros: The school is located in a good city with lots of fun events. There is happy atmosphere in this city and good weather.

review_title: It was a college that I went to  whici provided diverse eductions.

review_title: Relaxed place to focus on your research
job_title: Teaching Assistant in El Monte, CA

pros: Great lunch options, fair pay, friendly and welcoming environment

pros: Everything was great, the professors are nice and didn't mind if I had to study for a test and not come in a few days
cons: Nothing bad to say eveything was great I loved it a lot. 20 work min so blah blah blah blah b

pros: Good benefits, fun people. There are many people you meet at an international university. The job teachers.

pros: It was great to work at FIU. The assistantship under professor helped a lot in career development while studying at the same time.

pros: Resources are available everywhere. Beautiful campus.

pros: It was very convenient as a student to be able to attend class and head to work after. My bosses were incredibly understanding and everyone was so supportive

pros: healthcare packages, life insurance, retirement, paid tuition (6 credits only per semester) for self and children.

pros: Laid back environment without a lot of pressure. Good work life balance and good benefits. Generally good infrastructure as well.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Miami, FL

Benefits are great, health, eyes and dental can be insured for under $100!
Flexible work schedule

pros: Good people. Good work life balance.  Not a stressful environment.
